#Text=2. Distributed Decomposition Model
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Model Framework
#Text=The model has three parts ( i. e. , decomposition , prediction , and fusion ) .
#Text=In the decomposed node , the PM2.5 data are decomposed to three subsequences .

#Text=In the network training stage , each component is trained separately to obtain different sub-predictors ( i. e. , the trend component is trained to obtain ARIMA model , and the period and residual components are trained to obtain two GRUs ) .
#Text=The prediction framework is shown in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=.

#Text=In the prediction stage , the ARIMA model is used to obtain the prediction of the trend component , and two different GRUs are used to predict the period and residual components , respectively , before finally , all the predictions are added together to obtain the final predicted result in fusion node .
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=Decomposition
#Text=Assume that PM2.5 time-series data has N data , which means t = 1 , 2 , … , N .

#Text=The relation with and its three independent components ( i. e. , trend , period , and residual ) , as shown in Equation ( 1 ) . ( 1 ) where , , and are the trend component , period component , and residual component , respectively .
#Text=Then , we have to obtain these three components , , and from the one time-series data , but this is mathematically an unsolvable equation .
#Text=Each component has different frequency bands , that is , the trend and period component are in the low and middle band , respectively .
#Text=We used the cycle calculation process , shown in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=, to calculate the trend and period components until these two components tended to be stable and no longer changed .
#Text=In order to start the loop operation , we assumed = 0 in the first loop .

#Text=The time series is fitted iteratively until the trend and period component stabilize , and at the end of the cycle calculation process , the trend component and period component are extracted from the data series , and the residual component is obtained by ( 2 )
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=shows that the decomposition has two important steps : one is “ Remove high frequencies ” , and the other is “ Remove low frequencies ” .
#Text=Next , we will discuss the method of these two steps .

#Text=To remove the high frequencies , we used the locally weighted scatterplot smoothing ( LOESS ) smoother , which is based on fitting a weighted polynomial regression for a given time of observation , where weights decrease with distance from the nearest neighbor .
#Text=LOESS is a combination of the local fitting of polynomials and iteratively weighted least squares .

#Text=At each point x in the dataset , a linear or quadratic polynomial is fit using the weighted least squares , giving more weight to points near point x that need to be smoothed and less weight to points further away .
#Text=Suppose x is the point to be smoothed , is the number of data points around x to be smoothed , and is the point around x within the width .
#Text=We chose a Gaussian function as the weighting factor ( 3 ) where is a constant to be set .
#Text=It is always set according to the number of the data , and for PM2.5 , which is a complex nonlinear data , we suggest that it is set to as within .
#Text=The value of the regression function for the point is then obtained by evaluating the local polynomial for that data point .

#Text=By minimizing the value of the following ( 4 ) to find the parameter , then the smoothed value of point can be obtained by ( 5 ) and the LOESS fit is complete after the regression function values have been computed for each of the data points .
#Text=On the other hand , we used a high-pass filter with cutoff frequency to remove low frequency bands .
#Text=Obviously , it is critical to ensure that the loop converges to the trend component and the period component .
#Text=We chose the so called seasonal-trend decomposition procedure based on LOESS ( STL ) to achieve the loop convergence .

#Text=The STL method can adaptively adjust parameters according to each cycle calculation , so it can obtain good performance in ensuring convergence , and has many applications in data decomposition .
#Text=Here , we have omitted the details of the STL in order to focus our work ( please refer for the details of STL ) .
#Text=2.3 .
#Text=Autoregressive-Integrated Moving Average ( ARIMA ) Model : Prediction Model for Trend Component

#Text=In this paper , the ARIMA model was used and applied to model the trend component , by which the future value of is to be predicted based on the linear modeling function of the past trend value .
#Text=As a consequence , the time-series data that are fed to ARIMA should be linear and stationary .
#Text=It returns the dependent variable only to its lag value and the present and lag values of the random error term .
#Text=In terms of modeling , it is mainly divided into four steps as follows :
#Text=Step 1 : Import the raw data sequence to be predicted ;
